description: From Middle English exceden, from Old French exceder, from Latin excedō (“to go beyond”), from ex- (“out, forth”) with cedō (“to go”); see cede and compare accede etc. Partly displaced native Old English ofersteppan, whence Modern English overstep.

verbs.description: exceed (third-person singular simple present exceeds, present participle exceeding, simple past and past participle exceeded)

examples: The company's 2005 revenue exceeds that of 2004.
The quality of her essay has exceeded my expectations.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To go beyond (some limit); to surpass; to be longer than.
examples: Your password cannot exceed eight characters.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To go too far; to be excessive.
examples: And to speak impartially, old Men, from whom we should expect the greatest example of Wisdom, do most exceed in this point of folly […].
